listitem.para: 121Candida, Cryptococcus, and Other Yeasts of Medical Importance

para.ulink: FIGURE 1 Morphological features of some common pathogenic yeast species on cornmeal agar at 24 to 48 h and ambient temperature. (a) Candida albicans: blastoconidia, terminal chlamydospores, true hyphae, and pseudohyphae. (b) Candida krusei: extremely elongated, rarely branched pseudohyphae arising at 45, with few blastoconidia. (c) Candida kefyr: large numbers of elongate pseudohyphae and blastospores produced in a characteristic logjam. (d) Candida lusitaniae: short, distinctly curved pseudohyphae with blastoconidia formed at, and occasionally between, septa. (e) Candida parapsilosis: elongated, delicately curved pseudohyphae with branches arising at nearly 90, with blastoconidia at septa. (f) Candida tropicalis: blastoconidia formed at septa and between septa. (g) Candida glabrata: no true- or pseudomycelium; small oval budding cells only. (h) Saccharomyces cerevisiae: large oval to elongated blastospores, sometimes arranged as poorly formed pseudohyphae. (i) Rhodotorula spp.: large round to oval blastoconidia, occasionally in short chains. Magnification, 400.
FIGURE 2 (a) Appearance of Cryptococcus neoformans on cornmeal agar at 48 h and ambient temperature. Magnification, 400. (b) India ink preparation of C. neoformans. Magnification, 1,000.

FIGURE 3 Morphological features of less common pathogenic yeast and yeast-like organisms on cornmeal agar at 24 to 48 h and ambient temperature. (a) Trichosporon spp.: chains of arthroconidia with blastoconidia formed at the corners of arthroconidia. (b) Malassezia furfur: bottle-shaped, budding yeasts with annelloconidia and collarettes. (c) Ballistoconidia of Sporobolomyces spp. (d and e) Arthroconidia (d) and characteristic dichotomous branching (e) of Geotrichum candidum (Galactomyces geotrichum). (f) Sporangia of Prototheca wickerhamii containing sporangiospores. Magnification, 400.
FIGURE 4 Scheme for identification of yeasts from clinical specimens. Traditional methods are shown in beige.

FIGURE 5 Germ tube test. (a) Germ tube formation of Candida albicans; (b) blastoconidial germination with constriction (arrow) of Candida tropicalis not seen with true germ tubes of C. albicans. Magnification, 800. (Courtesy of B. A. Davis.)

FIGURE 1 Electron micrographs of the major developmental forms of Pneumocystis. (A) Trophic form attached to type I pneumocytes (arrowheads) and two larger trophic forms in the alveolar lumen (arrows); (B) sporocyte (precyst), note thickening of the cell wall (arrowhead); (C) ascus (cyst) with three visible spores (intracystic bodies) and characteristic thickening of the cell wall (arrow); (D) ascus with a spore that is apparently excysting (arrow), with two remaining spores; (E) collapsed ascus with no remaining spores, but with a released trophic form in the immediate vicinity (arrow). (Magnification, 10,000.)

FIGURE 2 Proposed life cycle of Pneumocystis. (A) Infection is initiated by inhalation of airborne asci. (B) Asci travel to the alveolar sacs (pictured in red), where they presumably release eight spores. (C) Putative sexual cycle of Pneumocystis: haploid trophic forms with mating receptors Map3 and Mam2 (M) fuse and undergo karyogamy, resulting in a diploid zygote; the zygote then undergoes meiosis, resulting in four nuclei; an additional postmeiotic mitosis increases the number of nuclei to eight; and the nuclei and mitochondria (not shown) are compartmentalized by invagination of the inner plasma membrane, resulting in eight spores within an individual ascus sporulation. (D) The mature asci are released from the infected host, likely by droplet nuclei, and are competent to infect another host. (E) The asexual replication cycle of Pneumocystis is undergoing reconsideration. Historically, it was assumed that the trophic forms underwent binary fission after mitotic replication of the nucleus. However, recent evidence suggests that there may not be an asexual cycle, or it is only operational under certain conditions (59).

FIGURE 3 Morphology and tinctorial characteristics of P. jirovecii in clinical samples stained with various stains (magnification, 1,000, unless stated otherwise). (A) Calcofluor stain of BAL fluid. Asci walls with internal thickenings (double comma) are highly fluorescent (color varies with barrier filter used). (B) Rapid Giemsa-like (Diff-Quick) stain of BALF. Thick cluster of mostly trophic forms (2 to 3 m) with small reddish-purple nuclei and light blue to red-violet cytoplasm. Boundaries of trophic forms are rarely discernible with this stain. Trophic forms overlay each other to produce darker-staining blue cytoplasm. Large dark purple host nuclei are admixed in the cluster. Arrow indicates an ascus with eight spores. The cell walls of asci exclude the stain. (C) Gomori methenamine silver stain (Grocott) of organisms from BALF. Asci walls can be observed as well as collapsed, cup shapes and crinkled raisin-like appearance. Note the lack of budding. Trophic forms are not stained with silver-based stains. (D) Papanicolaous stain of BALF. Note the distinctive alveolar cast morphology; magnification, 400. (E) Toluidine blue O stain of P. jirovecii in BALF. Asci walls are stained light purple. The crinkled appearance of the asci is illustrated with this stain, as well as darker central staining body. Note the lack of budding with this and other asci cell wall stains. Trophic forms are not stained. (F) Clustered asci of P. jirovecii stained with immunofluorescent-MAb anti-Pneumocystis jirovecii, from BALF. Note apple-green fluorescence.

FIGURE 1 Maximum-likelihood tree of pathogenic Aspergillus species as listed in the Atlas of Clinical Fungi, 4th ed. (http://www.clinicalfungi.org), based on ITS1 and ITS2 sequences of the rDNA gene obtained from GenBank using the program MEGA, version 7.0. Teleomorph names are given in parentheses.
FIGURE 2 Key to representative species of Aspergillus.

FIGURE 3 (A) H&E-stained section of lung showing Aspergillus hyphae with smooth hyaline which are septate and branch dichotomously at acute angles. (B) Colonies of Aspergillus fumigatus on potato dextrose agar showing typical blue-green surface pigmentation with a suede-like surface consisting of a dense felt of conidiophores. (C) Conidiophores of Aspergillus fumigatus are columnar (up to 400 by 50 m long) but may be shorter and are uniseriate. The vesicle is conical and has a singe row of phialides on the upper two-thirds. Conidia are produced in basipetal succession with long chains and are globose to subglobose. (D) Culture of Aspergillus lentulus. Colonies are suede-like to floccose, white, and interspersed with gray-green patches of conidia (conidiation is slow to poor). (E) Conidiophores of Aspergillus lentulus are short, columnar, and uniseriate. Stipes are narrower than those of Aspergillus fumigatus. Vesicles are subglobose and are smaller (6 to 25 m in diameter) than those of A. fumigatus (10 to 26 m). (F) Culture of Aspergillus flavus. Colonies are granular, flat, often with radial grooves, and yellow at first but quickly becoming bright to dark yellow-green with age. (G) Biseriate head of Aspergillus flavus. (H) Aspergillus nidulans (Emericella nidulans) showing cleistothecia. (I) Aspergillus ustus showing biseriate head, brown stipe, and Hlle cells.
FIGURE 4 White colonies of Talaromyces marneffei on Sabouraud dextrose agar (25C) with yellow-green conidial heads. With age, the diffusible brownish-red to wine-red pigment is evident.

FIGURE 5 Neighbor-joining tree of pathogenic Penicillium and Talaromyces species according to the Atlas of Clinical Fungi, version 4.1 (http://www.clinicalfungi.org), based on ITS1 and ITS2 sequences of the rDNA gene cluster obtained from GenBank using MEGA, version 7.0 (293).

FIGURE 1 (A) Member of Fusarium solani species complex (FSSC). Microconidia are borne on long monophialides (thin arrow). Macroconidia borne in aerial mycelium are also present (thick arrow). (B) Member of Fusarium oxysporum species complex (FOSC) bearing microconidia on short monophialides. A few macroconidia are also present. (C) Chains of microconidia produced by Fusarium verticillioides in F. fujikuroi species complex (FFSC). (D) Fusarium proliferatum in FFSC. Note polyphialides (arrows) with more than one conidiogenous locus per cell, and truncate conidia borne in chains and false heads. (E) Two-celled macroconidia of Fusarium dimerum in FDSC with centrally located septum. (F) Macroconidia of Fusarium delphinoides in FDSC. Note that the septum in two-celled conidia is off-center (thick arrow) and that a macroconidium with three septa (thin arrows) is also present. (G) Colony of Achaetomium strumarium showing yellowish surface mycelium and pink pigment on cornmeal agar after 5 weeks. (H) Glabrous and sterile colony of Gymnascella hyalinospora described in reference 141, grown on potato dextrose agar for 15 days at 30C.

FIGURE 2 (A) The same isolate of Gymnascella hyalinospora as in Fig. 1H turned yellow on oatmeal agar with clusters of ascospores after 15 days at 30C. (B) Ascospores of Gymnascella hyalinospora observed by scanning electron microscopy. Magnification, 6,000. (C) Perithecium of Microascus. (D) Brown ascospores of Cephalotheca foveolata formed after 8 weeks on carnation leaf agar at 25C. (E) Cephalotheca foveolata producing Phialemonium-like structures consisting of adelophialides (reduced phialides without a septum) and ellipsoidal conidia. (F) Tissue section stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain (Grocott stain) showing monokaryotic (clampless) hyphae of Schizophyllum commune/radiatum in a pulmonary fungus ball. (G) Schizophyllum commune/radiatum in slide culture preparation showing clamp connections and narrow pegs or spicules (arrows). Magnification, 580. (H) Dikaryotic culture of Schizophyllum commune/radiatum showing development of gilled fruiting bodies on potato dextrose agar after 7 weeks in the light.

FIGURE 3 (A) Setal hyphae of Tropicoporus tropicalis produced on potato flake agar, 10 days, 25C. Bar, 20 m. (B) Colony of Chrysosporium zonatum on potato dextrose agar after 14 days at 37C. (C) Conidia of Chrysosporium zonatum formed on short, curved stalks. (D) Rough-walled stipe, metulae, and phialides of Rasamsonia argillacea. Note the conidia are initially cuneiform (wedge-shaped). Bar, 10 m. (E) Conidia of Thermothelomyces thermophila in varying stages of maturity. Mature conidia are dark and rough. Bar, 10 m. (F) Culture of three different isolates of Arachnomyces nodosetosus (Onychocola canadensis) after 5 weeks on Mycosel agar. (G). Setae (appendages) of Arachnomyces nodosetosus (Onychocola canadensis). (H) Colony of Paecilomyces variotii on potato dextrose agar after 7 days.

FIGURE 4 (A) Colony of Purpureocillium lilacinum on potato dextrose agar after 14 days. (B) Verticillate conidiophores of Purpureocillium lilacinum bearing whorls of phialides. Bar, 10 m. (C) Yellowish colony of Thyridium curvatum (Phialemoniopsis curvata) on potato flake agar after 14 days at 25C. (D) Microascus gracilis showing asexual morph and an immature perithecium after 10 days on potato dextrose agar at 25C. listitem.para: 125 Agents of Systemic and Subcutaneous Mucormycosis and Entomophthoromycosis

para.ulink: FIGURE 1 Schematic drawing of morphological structures observed in Mucorales. Sporangiophores (A) bear sporangium-containing sporangiospores (D), can be anchored to the substrate by rhizoids (B), and expand by means of stolons (C). The columella (E) is produced at the apex of the sporangiophore, and in some species, an apophysis (G) is present. For some species, after liberation of sporangiospores, a thin sporangium membrane may be visible (F). Sporangia with a single or few spores are called sporangiola (H), and sporangia with few spores aligned in rows are called merosporangia (I). Thick-walled chlamydospores (J) and oidia (thin-walled swollen vesicles) (K) can be observed. Drawings by Dea Garcia-Hermoso.
FIGURE 2 Culture variability of some of the genera of Mucorales and their branching development.
FIGURE 3 Flow diagram for the identification of the different genera of Mucorales.
FIGURE 4 Lichtheimia corymbifera. (A) Branched sporangiophores; (B) hemispheric columellae and sporangiospores; (C) pyriform multispored sporangium and marked conical apophysis; (D) sporangiospores.
FIGURE 5 Rhizomucor pusillus. Sporangiophores with apical branching (A), simple rhizoids (B), and globose sporangia with round and smooth-walled sporangiospores (C and D) are shown.
FIGURE 6 Micromorphology of Mucor circinelloides. (A) Sporangiophore; (B) sporangia; (B and C) ellipsoidal sporangiospores; (D) oidia.

FIGURE 7 Actinomucor elegans. Branched sporangiophores. (A) Subglobose columella (arrow); (B) whorl of branched sporangiophores with secondary sporangia (arrow); (C) verticillately branched sporangiophore.

FIGURE 8 Cokeromyces recurvatus. (A and B) Mostly unbranched sporangiophores without rhizoids; (C) young sporangiolum; (D to F) recurved stalks arising from terminal vesicles and bearing few-spored sporangiola.
FIGURE 9 Apophysomyces elegans. (A to C) Unbranched sporangiophores (A) bearing multispored sporangia with a vase-shaped apophysis (B and C); (D) cylindrical sporangiospores.
FIGURE 10 Saksenaea vasiformis. (A and B) Unbranched sporangiophores with dark rhizoids and typical multispored flask-shaped sporangia.
FIGURE 11 Typical microscopic features of Rhizopus arrhizus. (A) Melanized sporangiophore arising opposite rhizoids; (B) striate angular sporangiospores.
FIGURE 12 Short pigmented sporangiophores arising in pairs in Rhizopus microsporus. (A and C) Rhizoids; (B) conical columella; (D) chlamydospores.

FIGURE 13 Cunninghamella bertholletiae. (A to D) Development of single-spored sporangiola on the surface of globose vesicles (A, B, and D), with frequent apical branching (C); (E) mature sporangiola grow to be single echinulate sporangiospores; (F) rhizoids.
FIGURE 14 Short sporangiophores arising from rhizoids (A), terminal vesicles covered by merosporangia (B, C, and E), and merospores (D) characteristic of Syncephalastrum racemosum.
FIGURE 15 Conidiobolus coronatus. (A) Ten-day-old powdery colony on PDA medium; (B) primary conidia with papilla; (C) passively released secondary conidium (arrow); (D) villose conidium.
FIGURE 16 Basidiobolus ranarum. (A) Ten-day-old, wrinkled colony on PDA medium; (B) uninucleate hyphal elements; (C) young zygospores.

listitem.para: 131Lagenidium, Paralagenidium, Pythium, Rhinosporidium, and Uncultivated Paracoccidioides Species (Formerly Lacazia loboi)

para.ulink: FIGURE 1 Phylogenetic location of the four groups of microbial pathogens studied in this chapter (based on small-subunit ribosomal DNA sequences). Forming a sister group, the Algae (Archaeplastida) and Stramenopiles (SAR) are placed basal to the plants (30). The latter includes the mammalian pathogenic Oomycota Pythium spp., Lagenidium spp., and Paralagenidium spp. They develop hypha-like elements, vesicles with biflagellate zoospores, and oogonia. R. seeberi is placed within the Opisthokonta, at the point where the Metazoa (animals) and Fungi diverge (red circle). This uncultivated protist is characterized by the development of spherical phenotypes with endoconidia. The uncultivated Paracoccidioides ceti, causing infections in dolphins, and P. loboi, pathogenic for humans, are anomalous ascomycetous fungi that develop yeastlike cells in chains.

FIGURE 2 P. loboi. Histological sections stained with H&E (A) and silver stain (B) show the typical morphological features found in human patients with Jorge Lobos disease. P. loboi yeastlike cells are poorly stained with H&E and are observed as empty round structures surrounded by an area of granulomatous reaction. (Bar, 15 m.) (B) The presence of abundant lemon-shape yeastlike branching cells in chains connected with slender tubes is the main feature of P. loboi in silver-stained sections. (Bar, 20 m.) (C) A skin biopsy wet-mount preparation in 10% KOH shows numerous P. loboi yeastlike cells in long chains, some of them containing small intracellular dancing bodies. (Bar, 20 m.)

FIGURE 3 (A) Colony of Pythium insidiosum on SDA showing a submerged colony with few aerial mycelia. (B) Slender, sparsely septate hyphae without fruiting bodies from culture. (Bar, 15 m.) (C) Vesicles of P. insidiosum containing numerous unhatched zoospores. (Bar, 30 m.) (D) Purple Medium (VPM) showing sucrose-positive P. insidiosum yellow colonies in primary isolation from biopsied tissue. (E) The development of oogonia in P. insidiosum is a rare event. The panel shows P. insidiosum oogonium from corn meal agar. (Bar, 10 m.)

FIGURE 4 (A) Colony of Lagenidium giganteum recovered from a dog with cutaneous lagenidiosis on SDA. L. giganteum develops cream to white submerged colonies at 25 and 37C. (B) L. giganteum on Purple Medium (VPM) showing a sucrose-negative colony, a typical feature of the genus on this medium. (C) Microscopically, ribbon-type hyphae highly constricted at septa are observed in samples from SDA plates. In lactophenol blue stain, the presence of large spherical and oval structures is common in some isolates. However, some strains may develop only hyphae. (Bar, 45 m.) (D) A 10% KOH preparation from biopsied tissue depicting several broader hyphal elements without septa. (Bar, 15 m.) (E) L. giganteum broad hyphal elements can be observed on Giemsa-stained biopsied tissue. (Bar, 15 m.) (F) L. giganteum vesicle still attached to the sporangial tube containing numerous zoospores from water cultures. (Bar, 25 m.)

FIGURE 5 (A) Pythium insidiosum hyphal elements in 10% KOH from biopsied tissue. (Bar, 15 m.) (B) Giemsa-stained P. insidiosum hyphae with lateral branches from a biopsied specimen. (Bar, 15 m.) (C) Gram-positive P. insidiosum hyphal element from a biopsied specimen. (Bar, 30 m.) (D) The Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is observed around P. insidiosum hyphae from a case of dog subcutaneous pythiosis (arrows). (Bar, 15 m.) (E) Silver-stained tissue showing the typical features of P. insidiosum hyphae in infected hosts. (Bar, 10 m.)

FIGURE 6 (A) Histopathological H&E-stained tissue sample from cat infected with L. deciduum (L. vilelae). Note the eosinophilic material (Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon) around hyphae 12 to 18 m in diameter (arrows). (Bar, 25 m.) (B) Tissue sample from Fig. 4D, stained with GMS, showing L. deciduum broader ribbon-like hyphae. (Bar, 25 m.)

FIGURE 7 R. seeberi. (A) H&E-stained tissue sample from a nose polyp showing mature sporangium (MS) with numerous endospores and JS of different sizes. (Bar, 500 m.) (B) Release of endospores from a MS. Note the presence of small endospores arising from the opposite side of the exit pore, a typical feature of the genus (arrow). (Bar, 80 m.) (C) Confocal microscopy of a tissue sample showing an immature sporangium containing R. seeberi parasitic stage, stained with DAPI and actin dyes. Note the presence of multiple nuclei (blue) within the cell and the binding of the actin probe (red) to the layer below the cell wall. (Bar, 25 m.) Image courtesy of Delfino et al. (77). (D) Three immature sporangia observed in 10% KOH preparation from a nasal polyp of a man with rhinosporidiosis. (Bar, 20 m.) (E) Giemsa impression smear from a dog with nasal rhinosporidiosis. An immature collapsed sporangium can be observed in the right section of the panel, with a few endospores on the left side (arrows). (Bar, 8 m.)

FIGURE 1 Diagram of a microsporidian spore. (A) Microsporidian spores vary in size from 1 to 10 m, with those infecting humans being from 1 to 4 m. The spore coat is thinner at the anterior end of the spore and consists of an electron-lucent endospore (En), an electron-dense exospore (Ex), and the plasma membrane (Pm). The sporoplasm (Sp) contains ribosomes, the posterior vacuole (PV), and a single nucleus (Nu). The anchoring disk (AD) at the anterior end of the spore is the site of attachment of the polar tube. It should be noted that the polar tube is often called the polar filament when it is within the spore prior to germination. The anterior or straight region of the polar tube that connects to the anchoring disk is called the manubroid (M), and the posterior region of the tube coils around the sporoplasm. The number of coils and their arrangement (i.e., single row or multiple rows) are used in microsporidian taxonomic classification. The lamellar polaroplast (Pl) and vesicular polaroplast (VPl) surround the manubroid region of the polar tube. The insert depicts the five polar tube coils in this figure in a cross section, illustrating that the polar tube within the spore (i.e., polar filament) has several layers of different electron density by electron microscopy. (B) Scanning electron micrograph (SEM) of Encephalitozoon intestinalis infecting a host cell (Vero E6) in tissue culture. The white arrow points to the extruded polar tube. (Both panels reprinted with permission from reference 40.)

FIGURE 2 Developmental life cycle of the microsporidia. Spores germinate when they are exposed to specific environmental conditions, which vary depending on the species of microsporidia. Upon germination, the polar tube is extruded and interacts with the host cell membrane, allowing invasion. The sporoplasm transverses the polar tube, is introduced into the host cell cytoplasm, and begins to proliferate. The morphology of the organism during the proliferative phase (indicated by the region above the dotted line) is used in classification systems defining the various microsporidian genera. Relationships of the various microsporidia with their host cells during the proliferative phase are described in Table 2. The left side of the figure illustrates the uninucleate sporoplasm: the microsporidian genera that are defined during the development of sporesi.e., the sporogenic phase (indicated by the region below the dotted line)are all uninucleate. On the right, the sporoplasm is diplokaryotic and all of the microsporidia genera defined during spore development have diplokaryotic developmental patterns. Regardless of whether they are uninucleate or diplokarytoic, there are three basic types of developmental forms. The first developmental pathway, as illustrated by Anncaliia spp., involves cell division by binary fission that immediately follows karyokinesis. The second type of pathway, as illustrated by some Nosema spp., involves multiple fission of elongated moniliform multinucleate cells. The third type of developmental pathway, as illustrated by Endoreticulatus spp., involves the division by plasmotomy of rounded plasmodial multinucleate cells. During the proliferative phase, cells can have one to several division cycles. Many microsporidia are either in direct contact with the host cell cytoplasm or closely abutted to the host endoplasmic reticulum; however, other microsporidia are found within a parasitophorous vacuole (e.g., Encephalitozoon spp. and probably Tetramicra spp.) or are separated from the host cell cytoplasm by a thick layer of their own secretions (e.g., Pleistophora spp.). In the sporogenic phase, this thick layer of microsporidian secretions becomes the sporophorous vesicle. During sporogony, several of the microsporidian genera, such as Enterocytozoon, Nosema, Anncaliia, Ichthyosporidium, and Tetramicra, maintain direct contact with the host cell cytoplasm. A sporophorous vesicle, illustrated by the circle around the developing sporogonial stage, is formed by the other microsporidian genera. During the developmental cycle of Thelohania and the Thelohania-like part of the Vairimorpha cycle, it should be noted that the diplokarya separate and continue their development as cells with isolated nuclei. (Reprinted with permission from reference 277.)

FIGURE 3 Identifying developmental characteristics of the microsporidian genera described as etiologic in human infections. (A) Anncaliia. Members of this genus are diplokaryotic and disporoblastic; the life cycle is like that of Nosema, but meronts are bizarrely shaped and possess a surface coat with vesiculotubular structures (vt) embedded in it and extending from it. (B) Vittaforma. Members of this genus are diplokaryotic and polysporoblastic; all stages, including spores, are isolated in a close-fitting, ribosome-studded cisterna of host endoplasmic reticulum (er). (C) Pleistophora. Members of this genus are monokaryotic and polysporoblastic; meronts and sporonts are multinucleate stages called plasmodia; a thick surface coat is already present on meronts and sporonts (1); this coat separates from the sporogonial plasmodium to form a cyst-like vesicle, the sporophorous vesicle; the plasmodium divides within it to produce numerous spores (2). (D) Trachipleistophora. Members of this genus are monokaryotic and polysporoblastic. The meront surface coat has branched extensions (1); these are withdrawn when the coat separates to form the sporophorous vesicle around a uninucleate sporont; the sporont undergoes a series of binary fissions (2, 3) and finally encloses numerous spores (4). (E) Encephalitozoon. Members of this genus are monokaryotic and di- or tetrasporoblastic; all stages of the life cycle, developing from the sporoplasm, occur concurrently within a host cell vacuole (parasitophorous vacuole); merogonic stages are appressed against the vacuole wall; sporogonic stages are free; the vacuole is finally packed with spores, so that it superficially resembles a sporophorous vesicle. (F) Enterocytozoon. Members of this genus are monokaryotic and polysporoblastic; meronts (1) have irregular nuclei and lucent clefts; sporonts (2) are multinucleate with rounded nuclei and have highly characteristic electron-dense disks, which are polar tube precursors; all spore organelles are formed prematurely, so that constriction around the sets of organelles and a nucleus (3) gives rise directly to almost mature spores. The surface coat is deposited only during constriction. (Adapted with permission from reference 278.)

FIGURE 4 Smear of a stool specimen from a patient with AIDS and chronic diarrhea, showing pinkish red-stained spores of Enterocytozoon bieneusi that measure 0.7 to 1.0 by 1.1 to 1.6 m. Chromotrope staining was used. Magnification, 1,000 (oil immersion). (Reprinted with permission from reference 278.)

FIGURE 5 (A) Terminal ileal tissue obtained by ileocolonoscopy from a patient with AIDS and chronic diarrhea due to Enterocytozoon bieneusi infection. Microsporidial spores, measuring 0.7 to 1.0 by 1.1 to 1.6 m, are found at a supranuclear location within small intestinal enterocytes. Brown-Brenn stain was used. Magnification, 1,000. (B) Cytospin preparation of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid from a patient with AIDS and intestinal E. bieneusi infection, showing intracellular microsporidia. Giemsa stain was used. Magnification, 1,000 (oil immersion). (C) Urine sediment from a patient with AIDS and disseminated Encephalitozoon cuniculi infection, showing pinkish red-stained microsporidial spores measuring 1.0 to 1.5 by 2.0 to 3.0 m. Chromotrope stain was used. Magnification, 1,000 (oil immersion). (D) Conjunctival scraping from a patient with Encephalitozoon hellem keratoconjunctivitis, stained with calcofluor white (chemifluorescent brightening agent that stains chitin), demonstrating the spores of this microsporidium. (Panels A, B, and C reprinted with permission from reference 278; panel D reprinted with permission from reference 277.)

FIGURE 6 Transmission electron micrograph showing the duodenal epithelium of an HIV-infected patient infected with Enterocytozoon bieneusi. The different developmental stages between the enterocyte nuclei and the microvillus border include a proliferative plasmodium (1), late sporogonial plasmodia (2), and mature spores (arrow). Magnification, 5,370. (Reprinted with permission from reference 278.)

listitem.para: 134 Mechanisms of Resistance to Antifungal Agents

para.ulink: FIGURE 1 Summary of major resistance mechanisms by drug class.

FIGURE 3 Schematic of biofilm composition and mechanisms of resistance showing effects on drug levels. (Adapted from Ramage et al. [212]).
FIGURE 4 Fks amino acid substitutions and polymorphisms in hot spot regions conferring reduced susceptibility to echinocandin drugs among clinical isolates of Candida spp.

FIGURE 5 Evolution of drug resistance. Drug action results in cell stress that, through cell membrane/cell wall receptors, activates downstream mechanisms that stabilize a subset of cells, resulting in elevated in vitro MIC values. In time, the cells develop well-characterized mechanisms leading to drug escape and clinical drug resistance. (Adapted from Healey and Perlin [37]).
FIGURE 6 Schematic overview of major cellular processes induced in response to inhibition of glucan synthase (Fks) by echinocandin drugs, resulting in cell wall stress and drug tolerance.

FIGURE 7 Negative carbol fuchsin staining according to Heine (15), showing an unstained, strongly refractile Cryptosporidium sp. oocyst on a pink to purple background. Image courtesy of Institute of Tropical Medicine Antwerp, Belgium (https://www.itg.be).

listitem.para: 139 General Approaches for Detection and Identification of Parasites

para.ulink: FIGURE 1 Processing liquid stool for O&P examination. Either Schaudinns fixative (zinc base with PVA) or one of the single-vial systems (with or without PVA) can be used for the preparation of the permanent stained smear. Organism motility is seen when saline is used; iodine kills the organisms, so motility will no longer be visible. The use of ethyl acetate may remove the entire specimen and pull it into the layer of debris that will be discarded (liquid specimen normally contains mucus); the liquid should be centrifuged at 500 g for 10 min (normal centrifugation time), but ethyl acetate should not be used in the procedure. In general, laboratories have switched to nonmercury substitutes; the original Schaudinns fixative contains mercuric chloride. However, in some instances the term Schaudinns fixative is still used to describe not the original fixative but a formulation that is prepared with a copper or zinc base or other proprietary compounds. When fixatives are selected, it is important to know the contents in order to comply with disposal regulations (10).

FIGURE 2 Processing preserved stool for O&P examination (two-vial collection kit). The formalin can be buffered or nonbuffered, depending on the laboratory protocol in use. Fixative prepared with mercuric chloride provides the best organism preservation. However, excellent alternatives are available, including zinc-based Schaudinns containing PVA, SAF, and one of the single-vial fixatives that requires no adhesive (PVA or albumin) (10).

FIGURE 3 Processing preserved stool for O&P examination (one-vial collection kit). There are single-vial collection systems for which the formulas are proprietary; however, many contain zinc sulfate as one of the key ingredients. With the exception of SAF, compatibility of these fixatives with immunoassay reagents is not always possible, particularly if the fixative contains PVA. Other options include Total-Fix (single-vial fixative with no mercury, formalin, or PVA) (Medical Chemical Corp.) and EcoFix (Meridian Biosciences, Cincinnati, OH). This figure provides three options for testing. In some cases, in-house validation procedures need to be performed prior to use. Commercial validation procedures are under way and should be available in the near future for some of these products. It is always important to read the package brochure carefully regarding the need for additional validation procedures.

FIGURE 4 Examples of iodine staining wet mounts (left) and permanent staining with Wheatleys trichrome stain (right). (Top row) Blastocystis sp. central body forms. (Middle row) E. coli cysts. (Bottom row) I. btschlii cysts. Note that in the Blastocystis sp. and I. btschlii preparations, the central body area and large glycogen vacuole clearly stain with iodine.

FIGURE 5 Modified acid-fast stains. (Top row) Cryptosporidium spp. oocysts, 4 to 6 m. (Note that the curved sporozoites can be seen in a few of the oocysts. These oocysts are immediately infectious when passed.) (Bottom row) C. cayetanensis oocysts, 8 to 10 m. These oocysts are not immediately infectious when passed. Note that some of the Cyclospora oocysts do not stain (modified acid-fast stain variable); also, some oocysts look like wrinkled cellophane (arrows).

FIGURE 6 Modified trichrome stains. (Top row) Microsporidian spores, 1.5 to 2.5 m; note the horizontal or diagonal lines within the spores (oval), evidence of the polar tubules. The left panel shows the Ryan blue counterstain, while the right shows the Weber green counterstain. (Bottom row) Microsporidian spores from eye specimens. (Left) Gram stain (note the resemblance to bacteria). (Right) Corneal scraping stained with a Gram stain (again, note the resemblance to bacteria). Misidentifications can result in inappropriate therapy and serious sequelae for the patient.

FIGURE 7 Examples of fecal immunoassays. (Top) Example of an enzyme immunoassay plate; these often come as 96-well trays or individual cup rows that can be inserted into a holder (courtesy of Techlab, Inc., Blacksburg, VA, and Alere North America, Orlando, FL). (Middle) Example of a combination Giardia-Cryptosporidium fluorescent assay (large organisms are Giardia cysts, and smaller organisms are Cryptosporidium oocysts) (courtesy of Medical Chemical Corporation, Torrance, CA). (Bottom) Example of a rapid cartridge for the detection of Giardia and/or Cryptosporidium (courtesy of Techlab, Inc., Blacksburg, VA, and Alere North America, Orlando, FL). Note that in this cartridge, both the Cryptosporidium and Giardia lines are positive, as is the dot control line.

FIGURE 1 The Plasmodium parasite is transmitted to humans when an infected female Anopheles mosquito takes a blood meal and inoculates sporozoites into the bloodstream (step 1). Sporozoites infect hepatocytes (step 2) and undergo asexual reproduction to form schizonts (step 3) in a process called exoerythrocytic schizogony (A). After 5 to 15 days, liver schizonts rupture to release hundreds of thousands of merozoites into the blood (step 4), which then infect erythrocytes (step 5). P. vivax and P. ovale have a dormant hypnozoite stage which may remain in the liver and cause relapsing disease weeks to months later, while other human Plasmodium species do not have this stage. In erythrocytes, merozoites undergo asexual reproduction to form trophozoites and then schizonts in a process called erythrocytic schizogony (B). Schizonts rupture to release merozoites, which then infect other erythrocytes (step 6). This process is repeated every 1 to 3 days, resulting in the production of thousands to millions of infected erythrocytes in several days. Some merozoite-infected erythrocytes do not undergo asexual reproduction but instead develop into male microgametocytes and female macrogametocytes (step 7). When ingested by a female Anopheles mosquito during a blood meal (8), microgametocytes exflagellate to release microgametes, which penetrate macrogametes and form zygotes (step 9) via sexual reproduction in the sporogonic cycle (C). Zygotes become motile and elongated to form ookinetes (step 10), which invade the mosquitos midgut wall and develop into oocysts (step 11). Over a period of 8 to 15 days, oocysts grow, rupture, and release thousands of sporozoites (step 12), which travel to the mosquitos salivary glands to be inoculated into a new human host during the mosquitos next blood meal (step 1). Image courtesy of the CDC DPDx (http://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/).

FIGURE 2 Plasmodium morphology on thick blood films encompasses the entire spectrum of forms, including trophozoites, schizonts, and gametocytes. Shown are P. falciparum early trophozoites in a moderate (panel 1) and heavy (panel 2) infection, P. vivax early trophozoites (panel 3), P. malariae (panel 4) and P. vivax (panel 5) schizonts, and P. falciparum (panel 6), P. malariae (panel 7), and P. vivax (panel 8) gametocytes. Neutrophils are shown for size comparison in panels 4 and 7. (Giemsa stain; magnification, 1,000.)

FIGURE 3 The ideal location for microscopic examination of a thin film is the region of the feathered edge where the erythrocytes have minimal overlap and maintain their central pallor (bottom, middle). In this location, the erythrocyte infected with P. ovale is clearly enlarged and ovoid. When examining similar cells in regions of the film that are too thin (bottom, left) or thick (bottom, right), the morphology is distorted and may be misleading.

FIGURE 4 Successive developmental P. falciparum stages in Giemsa-stained thin blood films, including early stage trophozoites/rings with a headphone form (panel 1), rings with Maurers clefts (panel 2), rings with appliqu forms and Maurers clefts (panel 3), maturing trophozoites (panel 4), early-stage schizont (panel 5), mature schizont (panel 6) (courtesy of the CDC DPDx), macrogametocyte (panel 7), and microgametocyte (panel 8). Rings (panels 1 to 3) and, less commonly, gametocytes (panels 7 and 8) are found in peripheral blood, while other stages (panels 4 to 6) are typically sequestered in the microvasculature.

FIGURE 5 Successive developmental P. malariae stages in Giemsa-stained thin blood films, including early-stage trophozoite/ring form (panel 1), birds eye ring form (panel 2), mature trophozoites with basket form (panel 3), mature trophozoite with band form (panel 4), mature schizont (panel 5), mature schizont showing rosette form with central pigment (panel 6), macrogametocyte (panel 7), and microgametocyte (panel 8).

FIGURE 6 Successive developmental P. vivax stages in Giemsa-stained thin blood films, including early-stage trophozoite/ring (panel 1), maturing ring (panel 2), mature ameboid trophozoites (panels 3 and 4), mature schizonts (panels 5 and 6), macrogametocyte (panel 7), and microgametocyte (panel 8). Note the Schffners dots (panels 2, 4, 6, and 8) and frequent molding of infected cells to neighboring erythrocytes. The infected erythrocytes are slightly larger than noninfected cells.

FIGURE 7 Successive developmental P. ovale stages in Giemsa-stained thin blood films, including early-stage trophozoite/ring (panels 1 and 2), developing trophozoite (panel 3), mature trophozoite with comet cell morphology (panel 4), early-stage schizont (panel 5), mature schizont (panel 6), macrogametocyte (panel 7), and microgametocyte (panel 8). Note the Schffners dots (panels 3, 4, and 8) and the oval/elongated shape of the infected cells (panels 4 and 6). The infected erythrocytes are slightly larger than noninfected cells.

FIGURE 8 Successive developmental P. knowlesi stages in Giemsa-stained thin blood films, including early-stage trophozoites/rings (panels 14), developing trophozoite (panels 57), developing trophozoites with band form (panel 8), early-stage schizont (panels 9, 10), mature schizont (panels 11, 12), and mature gametocytes (panel 1316). (Images reproduced from reference 45, with permission, CC-BY 2.0, https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0).

FIGURE 9 Cerebral malaria due to P. falciparum on tissue section (hematoxylin and eosin stain; magnification, 400). The capillary in the center of the image contains multiple infected erythrocytes, seen primarily by their brown-black hemozoin pigment.

FIGURE 10 Life cycle of Ixodes scapularis and Babesia microti. I. scapularis has a four-stage life cycle that generally lasts 2 years and includes vertebrate hosts (including rodents, deer, and humans), where each mobile tick stage has a blood meal on a different individual host. During the first year, mated adult female ticks detach from the vertebrate host to overwinter (step 1) and lay eggs in the spring. Eggs hatch in spring (step 2), and larvae attach to their first vertebrate host, usually small rodents or birds (step 3). The six-legged larvae feed on the first host, generally in late summer, and may become infected with B. microti while taking a blood meal. Engorged larvae leave the host, overwinter, and molt into nymphs (step 4). In the spring of the second year, nymphs attach to a second vertebrate host (e.g., rodents, deer, and humans) (step 5) and in the fall leave the second host to molt into adults and attach to a third vertebrate host, such as deer and humans (step 6). B. microti has a two-host life cycle including I. scapularis as the definitive host and a vertebrate intermediate host. In the tick (step 7), gametes ingested while taking a blood meal undergo sexual reproduction, leading to the eventual formation of infectious sporozoites. In the mammalian host (e.g., rodents or humans) (step 8), sporozoites initiate the erythrocytic cycle, resulting in the formation of trophozoites that divide asexually by budding. Subsequently, trophozoites transform into merozoites and perpetuate the erythrocytic cycle or into gametes, which are ingested by ticks during a blood meal to initiate the sexual cycle. All mobile stages of I. scapularis may acquire B. microti parasites from infected first or second vertebrate hosts, but only nymphs and adults transmit parasites. (Figure reproduced from reference 136, with permission.)
FIGURE 11 Babesia morphology on thick blood film consists of ring forms resembling trophozoites of P. falciparum. Some pleomorphism is apparent.

FIGURE 12 Babesia morphology on thin blood film. Note the presence of small intraerythrocytic ring forms resembling early trophozoites of P. falciparum, as well as thicker and markedly pleomorphic ring forms. Characteristic extracellular forms (arrow) and a tetrad form (arrowhead) are also seen.
FIGURE 1 The life cycle of Leishmania sp. (made by Dilhan Perera, laboratory of M. Ndao, using BioRender).

FIGURE 2 (A) Leishmania sp. amastigotes. The figure shows seven Leishmania sp. amastigotes captured from a touch-prep stained with Giemsa. The characteristic rod-shaped kinetoplasts can be seen in all the amastigotes depicted in the image (provided by CDC/DPDx, https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/leishmaniasis/index.html). (B) Two intact macrophages in a touch-prep stained with Giemsa. The macrophages are practically filled with amastigotes (black arrows), several of which have a clearly visible nucleus and kinetoplast. The red arrow shows an amastigote outside a macrophage (provided by CDC/DPDx, https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/leishmaniasis/index.html).
FIGURE 3 L. donovani amastigotes in a biopsy specimen obtained from a skin lesion preparation. Hematoxylin and eosin stain (provided by CDC/DPDx, https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/leishmaniasis/index.html).
FIGURE 4 L. donovani promastigotes in culture. Smear stained with Giemsa (provided by CDC/DPDx, https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/leishmaniasis/index.html).
FIGURE 5 The life cycle of Trypanosoma cruzi (made by Dilhan Perera, laboratory of M. Ndao, using BioRender).
FIGURE 6 T. cruzi trypomastigotes in peripheral blood stained with Giemsa. (Photo taken by Dilhan Perera, M. Ndaos laboratory.)
FIGURE 7 T. cruzi amastigotes in cardiac tissue stained with hematoxylin and eosin. (Photo taken by Dilhan Perera, M. Ndaos laboratory.)
FIGURE 8 The life cycle of Trypanosoma brucei (made by Dilhan Perera, laboratory of M. Ndao, using BioRender).
FIGURE 9 T. brucei gambiense trypomastigote in a thin blood smear stained with Giemsa. (Photo taken by Dilhan Perera, M. Ndaos laboratory.)

FIGURE 1 Life stages of T. gondii. (A) Unsporulated oocysts (source: ANOFEL, https://anofel.net/); (B) tachyzoites released from cell culture; (C) cyst from mouse brain tissue containing hundreds of bradyzoites.

FIGURE 2 Life cycle of T. gondii. (1) Unsporulated oocysts are shed in the cats feces and sporulate within 5 days; infectious sporulated oocysts contain two sporocysts, each containing four sporozoites. (2) Intermediate hosts in nature (including humans, herbivores, birds, and rodents) become infected after ingesting soil, water, plants, vegetables, or fruits contaminated with oocysts. (3) Sporozoites transform into tachyzoites, which replicate and disseminate, possibly infecting the placenta. (4) Materno-fetal transmission is possible during acute infection through bloodstream dissemination of tachyzoites. (5) Encystment in the brain, eye, muscles, or other tissues, following the immune response of the host. (6) Infection of carnivores (including humans) through raw meat containing cysts. (7) Cats become infected after consuming intermediate hosts harboring tissue cysts or by ingestion of sporulated oocysts. This figure was made partially using BioRender (https://app.biorender.com/).

FIGURE 3 Kinetics of antibody detection. IgG can be detected earlier or later than depicted here, depending on the technique employed. IgM can persist for a year or more. Ab, antibody; EIA, enzyme immunoassay; DT, dye test; IFA, immunofluorescence assay.

FIGURE 4 Illustrations of laboratory diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. (A) Microscopic diagnosis of acute pulmonary toxoplasmosis in a transplant patient with demonstration of tachyzoites (arrows) in a bronchoalveolar sample (MGG staining). (B) Histologic diagnosis of congenital infection at autopsy showing intracellular tachyzoites in a cord biopsy (arrows) (MGG staining). (C) Western blot profiles of paired mother (M) and newborn (N) sera showing neosynthesized antibodies characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis (red box).
FIGURE 5 Serologic interpretation of toxoplasmosis in patients aged >1 year and patient management according to the clinical setting.
FIGURE 6 Management of toxoplasmosis during pregnancy. *, given with folinic acid.

FIGURES 1 THROUGH 4 N. fowleri: (1) trophozoite, phase contrast (note the uroid and filaments [arrow]) (2); trophozoite, trichrome stain (3); biflagellate, phase contrast (4); smooth-walled cyst, phase contrast (note the pore [arrow]). All magnifications, approximately 835.
FIGURES 5 AND 6 A. castellanii: (5) trophozoite, phase contrast (note the acanthopodia [arrow]) (6); double-walled cyst, phase contrast. Both magnifications, approximately 835.
FIGURES 7 AND 8 B. mandrillaris: (7) trophozoite, phase contrast (8); cyst, phase contrast. Both magnifications, approximately 1,140.
FIGURE 9 Large numbers of N. fowleri trophozoites (arrows) in a section of CNS tissue, showing extensive necrosis and destruction of brain tissue. Magnification, approximately 564.
FIGURE 10 A. culbertsoni trophozoites (arrows) and a cyst (arrowhead) around a blood vessel in a section of CNS tissue from a GAE patient. Magnification, approximately 489.

FIGURE 11 B. mandrillaris trophozoites and a cyst (arrowhead) in a brain section from a GAE patient. Note the double (small arrow) and triple (large arrow) nucleolar elements within the nuclei of the trophozoites. Magnification, approximately 413.
FIGURE 12 Immunofluorescence localization of B. mandrillaris in a brain section from a GAE patient. Note the fluorescent amebae (arrows) around blood vessels. Magnification, approximately 188.

listitem.para: 144 Intestinal and Urogenital Amebae, Flagellates, and Ciliates*

para.ulink: FIGURE 1 FLIntestinal amebae of humans (Top row) Trophozoites E. histolytica is shown with ingested RBCs. This is the only microscopic finding that allows differentiation of the pathogenic species E. histolytica from the species E. dispar, E. moshkovskii, and E. bangladeshi. An ameboid form of Blastocystis spp. is rarely seen and is difficult to identify. (Middle row) Cysts. For Blastocystis spp. the central body form is depicted. (Bottom row) Trophozoite nuclei, shown in relative proportion.

FIGURE 2 (Top row) E. histolytica trophozoites (organism on the right stained with iron-hematoxylin). Note the ingested RBCs in the cytoplasm. (Middle row) Left, E. histolytica/E. dispar trophozoite; right, E. histolytica/E. dispar precyst. (Bottom row) E. histolytica/E. dispar cysts. Trophozoites without ingested RBCs, precysts, and cysts cannot be identified to the species level on the basis of morphology. Organisms are stained with Wheatleys trichrome stain. (Courtesy of L. Garcia.)

FIGURE 3 (Top row) Entamoeba hartmanni trophozoites (note the bulls-eye nucleus, very clear with compact karyosome). (Bottom row) E. hartmanni cysts (note that they often stop at two nuclei and contain many chromatoidal bars). All organisms are stained with Wheatleys trichrome stain. (Courtesy of L. Garcia).

FIGURE 4 (Top row) Left, Entamoeba coli trophozoite (note the uneven nuclear chromatin and large, blot-like karyosome); right, E. coli precyst (note the two enlarged nuclei, one at each side of the cyst). (Middle row) Left, E. coli cyst, iodine wet mount preparation (note the clarity of five of the eight nuclei and typical color using iodine); right, E. coli cyst (note that this morphology is exceptional and not always seen). (Bottom row) E. coli cysts. Cysts do not fix well with most fixatives; they often appear shrunken and distorted and display varying colors from red to purple to blue. Consequently, these cysts are often seen in a concentrated wet mount but are not clearly seen on the permanent-stained smear. Organisms are stained with Wheatleys trichrome stain unless indicated otherwise. (Courtesy of L. Garcia.)

FIGURE 5 (Top row) Left, Endolimax nana trophozoite (note the nuclear karyosome variation, which is typical in E. nana); right, E. nana trophozoite (note the more normal karyosome). (Middle row) Left, E. nana cyst (note the typical four nuclei); right, E. nana cyst (note the four nuclei, but also vacuole; cysts containing a single vacuole are not that rare). (Bottom row) Left, Iodamoeba buetschlii trophozoite; right, I. buetschlii cyst (note the single nucleus with a large karyosome and the large glycogen vacuole). Organisms are stained with Wheatleys trichrome stain. (Courtesy of L. Garcia.)

FIGURE 6 (Top row) Blastocystis spp. vacuolar forms (note the central body area stained with iodine; also note peripheral nuclei). (Bottom row) Blastocystis spp. vacuolar forms stained with Wheatleys trichrome stain. (Courtesy of L. Garcia).

FIGURE 7 Intestinal and urogenital flagellates of humans (Top row) Trophozoites T. vaginalis is found in urogenital sites; all other flagellates are intestinal. (Bottom row) Cysts. D. fragilis trophozoite is shown; putative cyst stage is not shown.

FIGURE 8 (Top row) Giardia duodenalis trophozoites (note the teardrop shape, two nuclei, linear axonemes, and curved median bodies). (Bottom row) G. duodenalis cysts (note that although there are multiple nuclei, they are not in the frame of focus in these images). All organisms (except the cyst on the right, iron hematoxylin) stained with Wheatleys trichrome stain. (Courtesy of L. Garcia.)

FIGURE 9 (Top row) Dientamoeba fragilis trophozoites (note the single, fragmented nucleus; if the nucleus has not yet fragmented, it will resemble Endolimax nana or Iodamoeba btschlii). (Middle row) D. fragilis trophozoites (note the two fragmented nuclei). (Bottom row) D. fragilis putative cysts (note that they appear to be shrunken with a cyst wall). All organisms (with the exception of the trophozoite with two nuclei on the right, which was stained with iron hematoxylin) were stained with Wheatleys trichrome stain. (Courtesy of L. Garcia.)

FIGURE 10 (Left) Pentatrichomonas hominis (note that the undulating membrane/arrow goes to the bottom of the organism, nonpathogen). (Right) Trichomonas vaginalis (note that the undulating membrane/arrow only goes halfway down the organism, pathogen). Both organisms stained with Giemsa stain. (Courtesy of L. Garcia.)

FIGURE 11 (Left) Chilomastix mesnili trophozoite (note the clear feeding groove or cytostome/arrow). (Right) C. mesnili cyst. Note the curved fibril sometimes called the shepherds crook. Also note the typical pear or lemon shape of the cyst. Both organisms stained with Wheatleys trichrome stain. (Courtesy of L. Garcia.)

FIGURE 12 (Left) Balantioides coli trophozoite (note the large macronucleus; the micronucleus is not visible). (Right) B. coli cyst (note the large macronucleus; the micronucleus is not visible). All organisms stained with Wheatleys trichrome stain. (Courtesy of L. Garcia.)

FIGURE 1 Line drawings of unsporulated and sporulated oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis (A and B) and Cystoisospora belli (C and D) and a sporulated oocyst (E) and sporocyst (F) of a Sarcocystis species from humans. Bar, 10 m.

FIGURE 2 Modified Kinyouns acid-fast-stained smears demonstrating Cyclospora cayetanensis oocysts (red) and an unstained, hyaline oocyst (arrowhead) (A); a stained Cystoisospora belli oocyst with a sporont (red) (B); and an unstained C. belli oocyst (arrow) with a sporont (arrowhead) partly obscured by counterstained stool organic matter (green) (C). Scale bar, 10 m.

FIGURE 3 Oocyst and sporocyst views under bright-field, differential interference contrast, and UV autofluorescence microscopy for Sarcocystis hominis (A through C), Cyclospora cayetanensis (D through F), and Cystoisospora belli (G through I). Scale bar for panels A through F is 10 m (C); scale bar for panels G through I is 25 m. Arrowhead (E and G) identifies an oocyst with a single sporont, while the arrows identify oocysts with two sporocysts each.
FIGURE 4 Hematoxylin and eosin-stained tissue section demonstrating several monozoic tissue cysts (arrows) of Cystoisospora belli. Note the thick wall that surrounds each single zoite. Bar, 10 m.

FIGURE 5 Sarcocyst (arrow) of a Sarcocystis species in a skeletal muscle biopsy specimen from a male Dutch patient obtained during an outbreak of muscular sarcocystosis (58) among visitors to Tioman Island off the east coast of Malaysia. A sarcocyst wall (arrowhead) surrounds hundreds of bradyzoites. Note the lack of inflammatory response. The patients traveling partner was also confirmed to be positive by muscle biopsy. Bar, 10 m. Image reprinted from Esposito, D.H., Stich, A., Epelboin, L., et al. 2014. Acute muscular sarcocystosis: an international investigation among ill travelers returning from Tioman Island, Malaysia, 20112012. Clin. Infect. Dis. 59(10):14011410. Published by Oxford University Press on the behalf of the Infectious Diseases Society of America, 2014.

FIGURE 1 Cryptosporidium parvum in the surface of the ileum of mice under transmission electron (A) and scanning electron (B) microscopy. In panel A, the organisms are intracellular, but are located between the two lipoprotein layers of the membrane (i.e., intracellular, but extracytoplasmic). Diverse development stages of the pathogen are seen on the surface of the epithelial cells. In panel B, some released merozoites (indicated by arrows) in addition to other stages (the globular structures) are seen.

FIGURE 2 Life cycle of Cryptosporidium spp. Sporulated oocysts, containing four sporozoites, are excreted by the infected host through feces and possibly other routes, such as respiratory secretions (1). Transmission of Cryptosporidium spp. in humans occurs mainly through contact with infected persons (for C. hominis and C. parvum) or animals (mostly for C. parvum) and consumption of contaminated water and food (2). Following ingestion (and possibly inhalation) by a suitable host (3), excystation (a) occurs. The sporozoites are released and parasitize epithelial cells (b, c) of the gastrointestinal tract or other tissues, such as the respiratory tract. In these cells, the parasites undergo asexual multiplication (schizogony/merogony) (d, e, f) and then sexual multiplication (gametogony), producing microgamonts (male) (g) and macrogamonts (female) (h). Upon fertilization of the macrogamonts by the microgametes (i), oocysts (j, k) develop and then sporulate in the infected host. Two different types of oocysts are produced: the thick-walled type, which is commonly excreted from the host (j), and the thin-walled oocyst (k), which is primarily involved in autoinfection. Oocysts are infective upon excretion, thus permitting direct and immediate fecal-oral transmission (courtesy of DPDx: http://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/). Note that data from a recent study indicate the presence of three merogony cycles with no clear differentiation of Type I and Type II meronts (266).

FIGURE 3 Oocysts of Cryptosporidium hominis (4 to 6 m) (A), Cryptosporidium muris (6 to 8 m) (B), Cyclospora cayetanensis (8 to 10 m) (C), and Cystoisospora belli (20 to 30 by 10 to 20 m) (D) stained with modified Ziehl-Neelsen acid-fast stain.
FIGURE 4 C. hominis oocysts (4 to 6 m) and Giardia duodenalis cysts (11 to 14 m by 7 to 10 m) under immunofluorescence microscopy.
FIGURE 1 Relative size of helminth eggs.

FIGURE 2 Various eggs of intestinal nematodes (magnification, 850). (A) Fertile egg of A. lumbricoides. (B) Decorticated fertile egg of A. lumbricoides. (C) Infertile egg of A. lumbricoides. (D) Egg of hookworm with thin shell and central morula. (E) Egg of Trichostrongylus sp. (F) Embryonated infective egg of E. vermicularis. (G) Egg of T. trichiura with polar plugs.

FIGURE 3 Larvae of intestinal nematodes. (A) Rhabditiform or first-stage larva of S. stercoralis showing short buccal cavity (arrow). (B) Rhabditiform or first-stage larva of S. stercoralis showing rhomboid genital primordium (arrow). (C) Rhabditiform or first-stage larva of hookworm. (D) Anterior end of rhabditiform S. stercoralis larva showing short buccal cavity. (E) Anterior end of rhabditiform hookworm larva showing long buccal cavity. (F) Tail end of filariform, or last-stage, larva of S. stercoralis with the notched tail (arrow). (G) Tail end of filariform, or last-stage, hookworm larva with tapering tail. (H) Agar plate culture showing tracks of bacterial colonies due to larval movement on the surface and inside the agar. The fecal specimen is placed in the middle of the plate and sealed, as larvae are infectious. (I) Fertile eggs of A. lumbricoides with hatching larvae. This is only seen in preserved specimens, although they sometimes hatch in formalin preparations if kept at room temperature (courtesy of Pam Smith, Royal Darwin Hospital). (J) Comparison of hookworm and S. stercoralis larvae.

FIGURE 4 Various adult worms of intestinal nematodes. (A) A. lumbricoides adult worm with typical cylindrical body with tapering ends and thick cuticle. The A. lumbricoides adult worm is the largest of the human pathogenic nematodes, 15 to 35 cm in length. (Arrow and inset) The three-lipped mouth distinctive of A. lumbricoides. (B) Adult worms of E. vermicularis in feces (arrow). (C) E. vermicularis adult female. Adult females are usually 8 to 13 by 0.3 to 0.5 mm in size. Shown is the anterior end of a female worm with the characteristic cervical alae (lips). Typical eggs can also usually be seen in the field. (D) E. vermicularis adult male. These are only occasionally seen in feces. Shown is the anterior end of a worm with the characteristic cervical alae (lips) (arrow). There is also a characteristic spicule at the posterior end (open arrow) (courtesy Pam Smith, Royal Darwin Hospital). (E) Parasitic adult female of S. stercoralis in the feces of a patient with hyperinfection. (F) Free-living female of S. stercoralis (with adjacent filariform larva) in culture.

FIGURE 5 Sections of adult female worms taken at colonoscopy/endoscopy (hematoxylin-eosin stain; magnification, 400). (A) Enterobius vermicularis female showing characteristic eggs (arrow). (B) Trichuris trichiura female (100) showing characteristic eggs (inset, 400). (C) Strongyloides stercoralis parasitic females in the small intestine (400).

FIGURE 1 Scoleces (top panels), gravid proglottids (middle panels), and eggs (lower panels) of, from left to right, H. nana, T. saginata, T. solium, and Adenocephalus pacificus. Note the coiled, central uterus in A. pacificus, the absence of hooks in the scolex of T. saginata, and the similar appearances of the eggs of T. saginata and T. solium. The morphological characteristics shown for A. pacificus are similar to those of D. latus.

FIGURE 2 Larval cestodes infecting the human host. (Top left) T. solium cysticerci in the human brain (neurocysticercosis), shown in a noncontrasted CT scan of the brain. (Top right) E. granulosus hydatid in the human liver (hydatid disease) as seen on liver ultrasound (kind contribution of Enrico Brunetti, Universit di Pavia, Pavia, Italy). (Bottom left) Echinococcus multilocularis alveolar hydatid disease in human liver (courtesy of K. Buttenschoen and P. Kern, University Hospital Ulm, Ulm, Germany). (Bottom right) T. multiceps coenurus showing multiple scolices in the cystic wall.

FIGURE 1 Five species of Schistosoma are known to infect humans. Infection with S. mansoni, S. japonicum, S. mekongi, or S. intercalatum adults occurs in mesenteric veins; S. haematobium adults infect the vesicle plexus. Humans are infected after cercarial penetration of the skin. After penetration, the cercariae shed their bifurcated tails, and the resulting schistosomula enter capillaries and lymphatic vessels en route to the lungs. After several days, the worms migrate to the portal venous system, where they mature and unite. Pairs of worms then migrate to the site of patent infection. Egg production commences 4 to 6 weeks after infection. Eggs pass from the lumen of blood vessels into adjacent tissues, and many then pass through the intestinal or bladder mucosa and are shed in the feces or urine (see the text). In freshwater, the eggs hatch, releasing miracidia that, in turn, infect specific freshwater snails (Table 1). Reprinted from the New England Journal of Medicine (108) with permission.

FIGURE 2 Life cycles of five foodborne trematodes, including intestinal flukes (Echinostoma hortense, F. buski, and H. heterophyes), a liver fluke (C. sinensis), and a lung fluke (P. westermani). Reprinted from Clinical Microbiology Reviews (59) with permission. Abbreviations and symbols: , diameter; n.s., not stated in original article cited in reference 59.

FIGURE 3 Eggs of schistosome species (magnification, 600). (A) S. mansoni; (B) S. mansoni egg with typical lateral spine not in view; (C) S. japonicum; (D) S. mekongi; (E) S. haematobium; (F) S. intercalatum. Panels C through E are reprinted from reference 32 with permission.

FIGURE 4 Eggs of trematode parasites. (A) F. buski (magnification, 500); (B) H. heterophyes (magnification, 1,500); (C) C. sinensis (magnification, 1,500); (D) O. viverrini (magnification, 1,500); (E) P. westermani (magnification, 600); (F) Nanophyetus salmincola (magnification, 750). Panels B through D are reprinted from reference 32 with permission.

FIGURE 1 Anisakid life cycle. Anisakids are gastric nematodes of marine mammals. Eggs that are released in the stool (step 1) embryonate (2a) and release larvae (2b) that infect crustaceans (3). The crustaceans are eaten by fish or cephalopod paratenic hosts (4), which eventually pass this parasite to the definitive host when it is eaten (5, 6). Humans become infected when eating raw or undercooked seafood that contains the parasite (7). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 2 This Anisakis species (arrows) has penetrated into the deep tissues of the abdomen. Multiple cross sections of the worm, which is 300 m in diameter, are seen in the omentum. Movat stain; original magnification, 2.5.

FIGURE 3 Trichinella life cycle. Humans may become infected by eating raw or undercooked pork or the meat of infected wild animals (step 1). Infection of animals is maintained in either domestic or sylvatic cycles. This nematode replicates within the small intestine of the infected human, resulting in the release of larvae that will encyst in muscle of the same individual (2 through 5). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 4 This coiled first-stage T. spiralis larva is in a nurse cell. Note the hyaline, amorphous appearance of the external aspect of the nurse cell and the surrounding chronic inflammatory infiltrate. The worm diameter is 35 m. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification, 30.

FIGURE 5 The Toxocara life cycle. This life cycle demonstrates the natural cycle of Toxocara within dogs and cats (steps 1 through 6), as well as the involvement of paratenic hosts (i.e., the rabbit and duck in this image, step 7). The cycle is completed within canines and felines through either the ingestion of eggs (3) or the consumption of an infected paratenic host (8). Humans become infected either through the direct ingestion of fertilized and embryonated eggs (9) or through the ingestion of improperly processed meat from paratenic hosts (10), with the resulting larva migrans (11). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).
FIGURE 6 The minute lateral alae are useful in the identification of Toxocara species. The worm diameter is 18 m. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification, 500.

FIGURE 7 The Dracunculus medinensis life cycle. This image demonstrates the contraction of infection by humans and dogs through the direct ingestion of infected copepods or the ingestion of paratenic and/or transport hosts (e.g., frogs and fish) (steps 1a and 1b). Ingested larvae then migrate to a subcutaneous location, mature, and mate (2, 3). Extrusion of the posterior end of the female worm releases larvae into freshwater (4), where they infect copepods and complete the cycle (5, 6). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).
FIGURE 8 The serpiginous tract of a female D. medinensis worm is demonstrated in the scrotum of this patient.

FIGURE 9 Rhabditiform larvae (short arrow) fill the body cavity of this gravid D. medinensis worm. Also note the presence of the two prominent bands of somatic muscle (long arrow). The worm diameter is 1.1 mm. Movat stain; original magnification, 25.

FIGURE 10 The Capillaria philippinensis life cycle. Infection proceeds following the ingestion of infected and undercooked fish (step 4). This nematode can complete sexual reproduction within the human host (step 5), releasing larvae capable of reinfection (6, 7) and thereby establishing an autoinfective cycle. Unembryonated eggs are also produced and released in the feces (1). These embryonate in the water (step 2) and, when ingested by fish, release the larvae that infect the intermediate fish host (3). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 11 The bipolar plugs (arrows), pitted eggshell, and rectangular shape characteristic of Capillaria philippinensis. This photomicrograph is from a human small intestine and demonstrates an egg that is 40 m long. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification, 490.

FIGURE 12 The Gnathostoma life cycle. Gnathostoma species infect a variety of mammals, forming a parasitic tumor in the stomach. Eggs that are passed in the feces (step 1) release larvae (2) that infect copepods (3), which are the first intermediate host. These are ingested by fish or frogs (4), which are the second intermediate host. The definitive host becomes infected by ingesting second intermediate host tissue (step 5) or paratenic host tissue (6). Humans also become infected through the ingestion of raw or undercooked meat from either a second intermediate or paratenic host. Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 13 The Parastrongylus (Angiostrongylus) cantonensis life cycle. Infection is maintained in the wild between rodents and snails (steps 1 through 4). Humans become infected through the accidental ingestion of snails or contaminated produce. Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 14 The immature P. cantonensis worm (arrows) in the meninges of this patient is eliciting a marked eosinophilic response. The worm is 200 m in diameter. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification, 50.
FIGURE 16 The coiled remnants of an immature male D. immitis worm are present in this branch of the pulmonary artery. The maximum worm diameter is 250 m. Movat stain; original magnification, 15.

FIGURE 15 The Dirofilaria immitis life cycle. The mosquito functions as the vector for the dog heartworm (steps 1 through 8). Humans become infected when bitten by a mosquito harboring the parasite larva (9). (9). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 17 The two uteri (arrows), muscle, and trilaminar and smooth cuticle (arrowhead) are characteristic of an immature female D. immitis worm. Internal cuticular projections can be helpful in identifying dead or dying worms. The worm diameter is 250 m. Movat stain; original magnification, 80.

FIGURE 18 Dirofilaria species other than D. immitis have external longitudinal cuticular ridges, whereas the cuticle of D. immitis is smooth. Dirofilaria tenuis, pictured here in cross section, is 270 m in diameter and has obvious cuticular ridges (arrows). Dirofilaria species other than D. immitis are often found in a subcutaneous location rather than in the pulmonary arterial vasculature. Movat stain; original magnification, 80.

FIGURE 19 The Baylisascaris procyonis life cycle. Baylisascaris is a geohelminth of raccoons and occasionally other animals. Although ingestion of embryonated eggs by the raccoon is the primary mode of transmission, larvae also may persist in small animal paratenic hosts (steps 1 through 6). Humans become infected through the inadvertent ingestion of embryonated eggs (steps 8 and 9). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 20 The Spirometra life cycle. Spirometra are cestode parasites of dogs and cats (step 6). Eggs that are passed in the feces must embryonate (steps 1 and 2), then the coracidia are released in an aqueous environment to infect a copepod (3) and transform into procercoid larvae (4). Fish or amphibians that eat the infected crustacean become the second intermediate host, in which plerocercoid larvae are formed. Dogs and cats that eat the infected second intermediate host complete the cycle. Humans similarly become infected by eating or using raw flesh (e.g., folk medicines) from the second intermediate host, or drinking unclean water containing infected copepods (step 8). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 21 A sparganum superficially resembles an adult tapeworm. Close inspection, however, clarifies its immature form, with a head with only a ventral groove or bothrium (arrow) and a lack of proglottids. The maximum width is 6 mm. Unstained; original magnification, 0.5.

FIGURE 22 The thick inner membrane of the egg of Hymenolepis diminuta is surrounded by a gelatinous matrix and then by an outer striated shell. The eggs of H. diminuta are spherical, whereas those of Hymenolepis nana are ovoid. The egg pictured here is 80 m in diameter. Unstained; original magnification, 250. See chapter 149, Cestodes, for more detailed coverage of Hymenolepis spp.

FIGURE 1 Triatomine bug (Triatoma sanguisuga). All kissing bugs have a similar body plan, with a dorsoventrally flattened body (often appearing crimped at the edge), folded wings, and cone nose. (Image courtesy of the CDC-DPDx.)

FIGURE 2 Bed bug, Cimex lectularius. (Left) Dorsal view; (middle) ventral view showing piercing/sucking mouthparts (from reference 11; reproduced with permission). (Right) Arm with immediate-type hypersensitivity reaction to bed bug bites acquired in a four-star hotel in Dupont Circle, Washington, DC, December 2005.

FIGURE 3 Fleas. (A) Cat flea (Ctenocephalides felis), showing typical flea morphologic features (from reference 11; reproduced with permission). (B) Histopathology section of the chigoe flea (Tunga penetrans) from a foot lesion, showing developing eggs (arrows).

FIGURE 4 (A) Head-and-body louse (Pediculus humanus) and nit (inset). (B) Pubic louse (Pthirus pubis) and nit (inset). P. humanus is longer than it is wide, has a thorax narrower than the abdomen, and has claws that are the same size on each leg; the nit has a flattened operculum. P. pubis is nearly as wide as it is long, has a thorax wider than the abdomen, lateral protuberances on the abdominal segment, and claws on the middle and hind legs that are larger than those on the forelegs; the nit has a raised, conical operculum. (From reference 11; reproduced with permission.) (C) Vagabonds disease. The trunk of people chronically infested by body lice becomes hyperpigmented and hyperkeratotic due to scratching. (Courtesy of Department of Tropical Public Health, Harvard School of Public Health, Boston, MA.)
FIGURE 5 (A) Human itch mite, Sarcoptes scabiei. (B) Follicle mite, Demodex folliculorum. (C) Northern bird mite, Ornithonyssus sylviarum. (From reference 11; reproduced with permission.)

FIGURE 6 Medically important ticks of the United States. (A) Lone star tick, Amblyomma americanum. (B) American dog tick, Dermacentor variabilis. (C) Black-legged or deer tick, Ixodes sp. (D) Brown dog tick, Rhipicephalus sanguineus. (E) Soft tick, Ornithodoros turicata. (Images A to D are adapted from reference 11; reproduced with permission.)
FIGURE 7 Tick hypostome (holdfast), showing recurved denticles that anchor the tick in the skin.

FIGURE 8 Pictorial key to adults of major tick genera in the United States. *, Hyalomma is not native to North America but may be found on travelers or immigrants from Africa, Asia, and southern Europe. (Adapted from references 11 and 16.)
FIGURE 9 Life cycle of Sarcoptes scabiei. Image courtesy of the CDC-DPDx.
FIGURE 10 Hands of a homeless individual with AIDS and severe scabies (crusted scabies) (courtesy of the Wikimedia Commons, Adam Cuerden; released into the public domain by author).

FIGURE 11 Pictorial key to the spiracular plates of the third instar of myiasis-causing fly larvae. Note that for some zoonotic species, second-instar larvae may be submitted to the laboratory for identification and possess spiracular plates with a different morphology (including one less slit and a weaker peritreme). Specimens identified by keying should be confirmed using other references. (From reference 11; reproduced with permission.)
FIGURE 12 Caterpillar urticaria: chronic scarring 2 months after exposure to brown tail moth hairs, Massachusetts, 2017.

FIGURE 13 Gradual engorgement of feeding ixodid ticks. (Left panel) Four-day feeding sequence of nymphal Ixodes ricinus, from unengorged (A), through partially engorged (B and C), to fully engorged (D). (Reprinted from reference 75 with permission of the publisher). (Right) Scutal index of engorgement for Ixodes scapularis (from reference 71; reprinted with permission of the publisher).
